author: game.changer.wallet
title: GameChanger: Most Wanted Features ❤
description: Devs and users frequently demand features and bugfixes. As a pure community driven Cardano wallet (no VC/token launch) we need some support

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal is at a B+/A-. It directly speaks to the developer experience in being drawn from feature requests of not just users but other developers, and these cover a lot of use case that would fall under developer ecosystem. In addition it is predicated on existing proven work, with specific aims to be fulfilled that would help the developer experience of Cardano as a whole.
f6_assessments.q1: Similar to the first assessment note, due to the previous experience and proactive integration in and with the Cardano community and ecosystem, there is little doubt that the initiators of this proposal could complete further work on an already operating piece of software (the GameChanger). However the roadmap milestones in this proposal are quite nebulous ("Combining all together with other new features being developed in paralel from other proposals.") when they could be far more directly succinct because that they were inspired from specific feature request feedback and should reflect that specific request feedback for instance as being the iterated set of objectives to complete and be measured against (at least, then it is possible to say "Combine it all and make sure it works with parallel development" and mean something). As any software project can succumb to technical debt let alone the million of other factors developer's face the objectives/roadmap detailed does not inspire much confidence as it is too general; not only is it too general, more specifically, since this is coming from an established project there should already be concrete metrics available from (d)app usage that should be a part of this proposal given how specific the rest of the proposal is: this is why I can't give it 5 stars.
f6_assessments.q2: Following the comments from the above assessment note, there main problem with this proposal is that its objective milestones/objectives are not measurable nor do they provide concrete numbers to provide a base line when they could because the GameChanger wallet is already widely used enough to have the feature requests used that were the very source of motivation for this proposal: that is to say definitive, concrete numbers could have been added to this proposal to offer both a point of reference and validity in terms of wanting to be accountable other than "us" assuming that if it works, it must be fulfilling said objectives when this doesn't have to be the case at all (those features could be dumped and substituted for something else, "we" wouldn't know). Furthermore, how could these objectives (such as "Finalize classes and methods.") be rendered as anything measurable to anyone who wrote or has read enough of the code base to know what this would even look like, let alone look like if it actually worked. What I'm getting at is, core to any functional software development is standardized quality assurance testing which this proposal provides no evidence of and is particularly important (if not necessary) for emerging technology and standards that change quickly; "we" don't know if the next update to cardano-node (or what would be equivalent for GameChanger) is going to break all the work that's been done. I'm talking about the green or red indicators you see whenever you are checking out a github repo (PASS / FAIL): having these kind of tests would also provide a key metric for not only success of fulfilling the stated objectives, but show explicit evidence the development team is commited to making quality software that enriches the development ecosystem (for itself and as a model standard for other projects/developers). I --strongly-- encourage that a systematic set of tests be integrated into this proposal/project in future rounds/work for it to get the funding it deserves.

f6_assessments.q0:
From the problem statement it is not clear what the proposer is trying to solve. The problem statement also does not match with the rest of the proposal content. The problem statement can be interpreted as :“We have bugs, we want non venture capital money”, however the rest of the proposal says “We have this new unique wallet that performs more than one action with each transaction.”

This proposal aims to provide its users with an interface to facilitate minting, create multi-output transactions and native token minting, however I struggle to see what the specific benefit is for developers. The latter portions of the proposal describe the solution as “Sometimes we have been referred as an easier (low-code and automated) *cardano-wallet-cli web alternative”.*

As an engineer myself, I struggle to see the benefit of this proposal to developers, given that it is posted in the Developer Ecosystem Challenge. I would consider this proposal more appropriate for the Dapps and Integrations challenge. It is also not entirely clear what the problem is that the team is trying to solve. Are you wanting to make the cardano-cli easier to use? Are you making a wallet with an API? What is the developer problem/need that you are solving? This is my rationale for a 3 star impact rating
f6_assessments.q1:
The team appears to be very capable in working towards the solution it mentions. I would strongly advise that the team define success at smaller intervals. To define success as being the successful outcome AFTER 6 months of work is not a very good project management approach (1 star deduction). 

The budget does however seem rather reasonable and the funding amount requested seems to match with the team’s allocated tasks.
f6_assessments.q2:
User feedback is also not generally a holistic picture of what progress looks like nor is it a good metric to measure the auditiability of a project. The purpose of auditability is to answer the: “How can a community member make sure you are not misappropriating funds, if funded” question. I do not think that question was answered in the Auditability section of the proposal. (Hence a 1 star deduction). 

Placing your first measure of success at the 4 month mark in a 6 month proposal, means that more than half of your work would need to be done before your first progress check. As an engineer and technical founder, this is not a good approach to management of a developer project. (Hence a subsequent 1 star deduction)

f6_assessments.q0: I believe that by owning four functionalities, the project will be able to overcome the problem that still exists in the Cardano ecosystem. The proposer, in particular, emphasized that their GameChanger wallet will allow users to mix many Cardano features at once into single transactions from day one, allowing for sustainable network usage and lower costs. This functionality will significantly enhance the Cardano ecosystem's wallet quality while also increasing user trust and pleasure. However, I don't see what is required to foresee future hazards. The proposal just highlights the product's characteristics, but the necessity of this part is to indicate probable future issues as well as concrete remedies. As a result, I feel that if that section is added, the project will be approved for work.
f6_assessments.q1: In this part, I give them the maximum score because everything is prepared very carefully and meticulously. Proposer wants to finish all activities in four months, with four separate phases, and then formally put them into Cardano for users to experience. They specifically mentioned the current state of the wallet as well as the features to demonstrate why their project is deserving of such approval. And of course, to make such a complete plan, it is indispensable for the efforts of the team members. The group comprises five people, practically most of whom have more than ten years of industry experience. Finally, the proposer plans to use the budget split to compensate full-time and part-time engineers. Because the salary is not that small, so perhaps I just want the proposer to be able to point out what they will do to ensure that the salary paid to them is completely worthy and transparent.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposer has provided explicit timetables for assessing the project's development. This is an advantage that allows specialists to have a more in-depth understanding of the project. As well as helping investors believe that the money they spend on the project is completely worth it. However, the achievements they described are not as informative as I hoped. Instead of merely providing generic suggestions, the proposer should choose the most remarkable outcomes to help the project stand out. As a result, please include it as soon as possible because it occupies a significant portion of the final section of this project.

f6_assessments.q0: The overall idea, the project proposal, and the overall defined tasks and milestones sounded like a sensible idea to me, not just for the desired investment value but also for the overall project proposal. In addition, the project's concept and construction appear to be well-designed. A dedicated session that focuses on effect is also beneficial because it clarifies the value offered. This suggestion adds a significant amount of value to the Carnado ecosystem. Even if it is already at a good stage, the proposer offers enough explicit details so that all readers can grasp it. A dedicated session that focuses on effect is also beneficial because it clarifies the value offered. As a recommendation, make these report metrics as visual as possible, using graphs and dashboards or something similar, so users can understand the amount of the backlog and where the tasks are in the process. I'd only like to see a directory where I could save "proofs"/evidence of accomplishments as documents
f6_assessments.q1: The proposal timetable and milestones are clearly defined; the proposed timescale of four months can be met based on the evidence, track record, and team allocated. The team is made up of numerous members of the Catalyst community that are not only very active in the community but also have experience delivering on previous initiatives and projects. Their abilities and knowledge are well-balanced, resulting in a broad and well-prepared team. The team is already devoted and experienced in numerous knowledge areas, which is important and will aid the project's progress. There are links that can be used to double-check the facts (Linkedin links, for example). There is a well-thought-out timetable, which is excellent. The budget breakdown is reasonable, but it might be more thorough. However, I wouldn't penalize much for this, and I believe it still earned a 5-star rating for overall viability
f6_assessments.q2: For the next level of funding, the success criteria are valid and relevant; nevertheless, I find the specified measures challenging to measure. If possible, I recommend examining the metrics prior to the launch to avoid confusion among future proposers. I'd simply ask if the team could set concrete goals for itself at the end of the six-month project. I agree that the success criteria and the metrics for measuring progress in tackling the challenge are appropriate.

f6_assessments.q0: This is an active project under development within the Cardano ecosystem. It seems to be a project that will benefit the overall ecosystem in the long term. I think this does fall within the parameters of the F8 Developer Ecosystem challenge.
f6_assessments.q1: The team seems to have a lot of technical experience based on their descriptions in this proposal and their respective Linkedin profiles. The proposer has accounted for how the requested funding would be allocated. The goals outlined are reasonably specific as well. The proposer (Adrian Fiorenza) is also a member of the Gimbal Labs team, (https://gimbalabs.com/team) which indicates that he is committed to the overall growth of the Cardano Ecosystem. Based on these facts, I think it is very reasonable to think this will be implemented successfully
f6_assessments.q2: The end goals in terms of software development are clearly stated. The benchmarks for success from an adoption standpoint have also been clearly stated. I think that the information is sufficient to judge the success and progress of the proposal.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal is an extension of an existing project. it basically about building features and improvements on its infrastructure. It aims to create  an improved user experience with features  that will provide an enabling environment for developers to  use build and develop dApps and other activities, and making their work easier to work with the GameChanger Wallet to develop easily. The proposal is definitely within the challenge objectives and goals of providing an environment for developers to thrive.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposal has provided a detailed profile of the proposers with necessary links which confirms their capacity to implement this project successfully. The proposal's budget analysis was well explained and in addition, the Milestones are reasonable and achievable within the time specified. However, marketing and promotional efforts were not budgeted  to onboard new users.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal provided a detailed roadmap of the implementation plan and the time frame. This indicated milestones can also act as a relevant basis to assess its performance . However, there were no quantifiable  measures to monitor success of the project if funded as all the presented metrics are vague and unmeasurable for proper assessment.

solution: Help us provide dedicated support to our users. DApp API and UI improvements, keys persistance UX, stake multi delegation, and much more
experience: GameChanger Finance delivers great value with its next generation wallet and dapps, teaming up Gimbalabs,Dandelion,Yoroi and now IOHK contributors worldwide. GC Wallet is highly graphical and gamified, committed to newcomers, students and builders, lowering Cardano entry barriers
